warning_device_squawk.name: Warning device squawk
warning_device_squawk.description: This service uses the WD capabilities to emit a quick audible/visible pulse called a "squawk". The squawk command has no effect if the WD is currently active (warning in progress).

mode.name: Mode
mode.description: The Squawk Mode field is used as a 4-bit enumeration, and can have one of the values shown in Table 8-24 of the ZCL spec - Squawk Mode Field. The exact operation of each mode (how the WD “squawks”) is implementation specific.

strobe.name: Strobe
strobe.description: The strobe field is used as a Boolean, and determines if the visual indication is also required in addition to the audible squawk, as shown in Table 8-25 of the ZCL spec - Strobe Bit.

level.name: Level
level.description: The squawk level field is used as a 2-bit enumeration, and determines the intensity of audible squawk sound as shown in Table 8-26 of the ZCL spec - Squawk Level Field Values.

warning_device_warn.name: Warning device starts alert
warning_device_warn.description: This service starts the operation of the warning device. The warning device alerts the surrounding area by audible (siren) and visual (strobe) signals.

mode.name: Mode
mode.description: The Warning Mode field is used as a 4-bit enumeration, can have one of the values 0-6 defined below in table 8-20 of the ZCL spec. The exact behavior of the warning device in each mode is according to the relevant security standards.

strobe.name: Strobe
strobe.description: The Strobe field is used as a 2-bit enumeration, and determines if the visual indication is required in addition to the audible siren, as indicated in Table 8-21 of the ZCL spec. "0" means no strobe, "1" means strobe. If the strobe field is “1” and the Warning Mode is “0” (“Stop”), then only the strobe is activated.

level.name: Level
level.description: The Siren Level field is used as a 2-bit enumeration, and indicates the intensity of audible squawk sound as shown in Table 8-22 of the ZCL spec.

duration.name: Duration
duration.description: Requested duration of warning, in seconds (16 bit). If both Strobe and Warning Mode are "0" this field is ignored.

duty_cycle.name: Duty cycle
duty_cycle.description: Indicates the length of the flash cycle. This allows you to vary the flash duration for different alarm types (e.g., fire, police, burglar). The valid range is 0-100 in increments of 10. All other values must be rounded to the nearest valid value. Strobe calculates a duty cycle over a duration of one second. The ON state must precede the OFF state. For example, if the Strobe Duty Cycle field specifies “40,”, then the strobe flashes ON for 4/10ths of a second and then turns OFF for 6/10ths of a second.

intensity.name: Intensity
intensity.description: Indicates the intensity of the strobe as shown in Table 8-23 of the ZCL spec. This attribute is designed to vary the output of the strobe (i.e., brightness) and not its frequency, which is detailed in section 8.4.2.3.1.6 of the ZCL spec.

warning_device_squawk.name: Warning device squawk
warning_device_squawk.description: This service uses the WD capabilities to emit a quick audible/visible pulse called a "squawk". The squawk command has no effect if the WD is currently active (warning in progress).

mode.name: Mode
mode.description: The Squawk Mode field is used as a 4-bit enumeration, and can have one of the values shown in Table 8-24 of the ZCL spec - Squawk Mode Field. The exact operation of each mode (how the WD “squawks”) is implementation specific.

strobe.name: Strobe
strobe.description: The strobe field is used as a Boolean, and determines if the visual indication is also required in addition to the audible squawk, as shown in Table 8-25 of the ZCL spec - Strobe Bit.

level.name: Level
level.description: The squawk level field is used as a 2-bit enumeration, and determines the intensity of audible squawk sound as shown in Table 8-26 of the ZCL spec - Squawk Level Field Values.

warning_device_warn.name: Warning device starts alert
warning_device_warn.description: This service starts the operation of the warning device. The warning device alerts the surrounding area by audible (siren) and visual (strobe) signals.

mode.name: Mode
mode.description: The Warning Mode field is used as a 4-bit enumeration, can have one of the values 0-6 defined below in table 8-20 of the ZCL spec. The exact behavior of the warning device in each mode is according to the relevant security standards.

strobe.name: Strobe
strobe.description: The Strobe field is used as a 2-bit enumeration, and determines if the visual indication is required in addition to the audible siren, as indicated in Table 8-21 of the ZCL spec. "0" means no strobe, "1" means strobe. If the strobe field is “1” and the Warning Mode is “0” (“Stop”), then only the strobe is activated.

level.name: Level
level.description: The Siren Level field is used as a 2-bit enumeration, and indicates the intensity of audible squawk sound as shown in Table 8-22 of the ZCL spec.

duration.name: Duration
duration.description: Requested duration of warning, in seconds (16 bit). If both Strobe and Warning Mode are "0" this field is ignored.

duty_cycle.name: Duty cycle
duty_cycle.description: Indicates the length of the flash cycle. This allows you to vary the flash duration for different alarm types (e.g., fire, police, burglar). The valid range is 0-100 in increments of 10. All other values must be rounded to the nearest valid value. Strobe calculates a duty cycle over a duration of one second. The ON state must precede the OFF state. For example, if the Strobe Duty Cycle field specifies “40,”, then the strobe flashes ON for 4/10ths of a second and then turns OFF for 6/10ths of a second.

intensity.name: Intensity
intensity.description: Indicates the intensity of the strobe as shown in Table 8-23 of the ZCL spec. This attribute is designed to vary the output of the strobe (i.e., brightness) and not its frequency, which is detailed in section 8.4.2.3.1.6 of the ZCL spec.

en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.migrate.para_no: This element doesn't have an ID. Please add an ID to this element in 'ui-lovelace.yaml'.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.migrate.para_mi: Home Assistant can add IDs to all your cards and views automatically for you by pressing the 'Migrate configuration' button.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.alarm-pane: The Alarm Panel card allows you to arm and disarm your alarm control panel integrations.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.area.name: Area
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.area.descr: The Area card automatically displays entities of a specific area.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.area.show_: Show camera feed instead of area picture
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.calendar.d: The Calendar card displays a calendar including day, week and list views
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.conditiona: The Conditional card displays another card based on entity states.
The card will be shown when ALL conditions below are fulfilled.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.entities.d: The Entities card is the most common type of card. It groups items together into lists.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.entities.e: View the details of this row by clicking the edit button
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.entity.des: The Entity card gives you a quick overview of your entity's state.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.button.des: The Button card allows you to add buttons to perform tasks.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.button.def: The default action depends on the entity's capabilities, it will either be toggled or the more info dialog will be shown.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.entity-fil: The Entity Filter card allows you to define a list of entities that you want to track only when in a certain state.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.gauge.name: Gauge
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.gauge.desc: The Gauge card is a basic card that allows visually seeing sensor data.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.glance.des: The Glance card is useful to group multiple sensors in a compact overview.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.grid.name: Grid
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.grid.descr: The Grid card allows you to show multiple cards in a grid.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.logbook.de: The Logbook card shows a list of events for entities.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.history-gr: The History Graph card allows you to display a graph for each of the entities listed.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.statistics: The Statistics Graph card allows you to display a graph of the statistics for each of the entities listed.
The Statistic card allows you to display a statistical value of an entity of a certain period.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.horizontal: The Horizontal Stack card allows you to stack together multiple cards, so they always sit next to each other in the space of one column.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.humidifier: The Humidifier card gives control of your humidifier entity. Allowing you to change the humidity and mode of the entity.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.iframe.des: The Webpage card allows you to embed your favorite webpage right into Home Assistant.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.light.name: Light
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.light.desc: The Light card allows you to change the brightness of the light.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.generic.ma: Need to add a custom card or just want to manually write the YAML?
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.generic.pa: Paste a {type} card from the clipboard
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.map.name: Map
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.map.descri: The Map card that allows you to display entities on a map.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.markdown.d: The Markdown card is used to render Markdown.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.media-cont: The Media Control card is used to display media player entities on an interface with easy to use controls.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.picture.de: The Picture card allows you to set an image to use for navigation to various paths in your interface or to call a service.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.picture-el: The Picture Elements card is one of the most versatile types of cards. The cards allow you to position icons or text and even services! On an image based on coordinates.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.picture-en: The Picture Entity card displays an entity in the form of an image. Instead of images from URL, it can also show the picture of camera entities.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.picture-gl: The Picture Glance card shows an image and corresponding entity states as an icon. The entities on the right side allow toggle actions, others show the more info dialog.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.plant-stat: The Plant Status card is for all the lovely botanists out there.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.sensor.des: The Sensor card gives you a quick overview of your sensors state with an optional graph to visualize change over time.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.shopping-l: The Shopping List card allows you to add, edit, check-off, and clear items from your shopping list.
This card requires the `shopping_list` integration to be set up.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.thermostat: The Thermostat card gives control of your climate entity. Allowing you to change the temperature and mode of the entity.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.tile.name: Tile
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.tile.descr: The tile card gives you a quick overview of your entity. The card allow you to toggle the entity, show the more info dialog or custom actions.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.tile.featu: No compatible features available for this entity
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.vertical-s: The Vertical Stack card allows you to group multiple cards so they always sit in the same column.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.card.weather-fo: The Weather Forecast card displays the weather. Very useful to include on interfaces that people display on the wall.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.editor.view.panel_mode: This view contains more than one card, but a panel view can only show 1 card.
en.ui.panel.lovelace.warning.starting: Home Assistant is starting, not everything may be available yet
en.ui.panel.lovelace.changed_toast.message: Your dashboard was updated. Refresh to see changes?
